Legal_Issue: Whether the profit from the sale of the Cusson property is a capital gain or ordinary income
Governing_Law: Tax laws governing classification of real estate profits
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiffs' history of buying and selling properties; timing of listing the Cusson property for sale
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiffs to demonstrate capital gain treatment
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiffs' pattern of real estate transactions
Legal_Rule: Profit from real estate is taxable as income if taxpayer was in the business of trading or had intention to resell at acquisition
Standard_of_Review: Based on facts and legal precedents
Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over tax treatment of property sale proceeds
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fair trial based on evidence and legal analysis
Key_Evidence_Considered: Multiple property transactions by plaintiffs; early listing of Cusson property
Legal_Framework: Income tax law, capital gains vs. ordinary income doctrine
Applicant_Challenge: Seeking capital gain treatment for profit
Court_Result: Ruled in favor of tax authority
Defendant_Response: Argued profit was ordinary income due to intent and activity
Remedy_Requested: Favorable tax treatment as capital gain
Outcome: Denied; profit classified as ordinary income
Legal_Provision: Relevant income tax provisions on capital gains and ordinary income
Legal_Provision_Cited: Rules on real estate profit taxation
Governing_Rule: Intent and frequency of transactions determine income classification
